posts.post_content: I very strongly disagree with people that rate this card poorly. Granted there are very few decks that can play him, but in those that can he is brilliant. I play a 5 color planeswalker deck that gets up to over ten mana every game and can survive for that long EVERY game. (It is very different than AJ Sachers build) With Wraths, Condemns, Volcanic Fallouts, Austere Commands, planewalkers (esp. Garruk), etc. it is very easy to get up the mana. Some people say it is worse than Cruel Ultimatum and that is probably true in the typical 5 color control decks but in my planeswalker deck this is clearly better. In my deck each players life totals are largely irrelevant because I rarely go below 10 life and have ajani goldmane to usually keep above 20 and I usually do not win by chipping away my opponents life total. The deck also runs 0 creatures main and 0 creatures side, so the pulling the creature from your gy never happens. Forcing the opponent to sac one creature is generally in... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
you can make it work, but it is difficult, 8 mana is a big ouch but considering, it is appropriate for the card  
  
try and work on a combo to increase the loyalty counters quickly, for example, gilder bairn: destroy something on Nicol's first turn out, then second turn, find a way to tap gilder bairn and find 2U to untap it and double the 8 counters on Nicol, he now has 16 and can unleash his master ability with 7 counters left, but why stop there, what was good once is good again right? whatever you used to tap gilder bairn before, use again, then another 2U and Nicol is at 32, 3 straight turns to activate Nicol's master ability, even with some damage and gilder bairn being knocked out (your opponent is a fool if he lets this combo continue beyond 1 turn)

posts.post_content: I just got him in a pack the other day and I use him, but only because I can. I don't think anyone can deny the fact that this card has to be one of the most powerful plainswalkers, but there are certain rules everyone must know before even thinking of putting one of them in their deck. In my opinion, one major factor you have to remeber is "Don't rely on the plainswalker only to win your duels". If you focus on that only, the chances of winning may be much slimmer. You always have to have a back up strategy just incase you don't happen to draw the card throughout the duel. Onc you do, and you have a killer strategy, chances are you'll probably win. Trust me I have Nicol Bolas and if I draw him and play him I 98% of the time win the duel. This statement is from my own personal experiences. !!! :) !!!

Posted By: Gako (3/21/2009 6:50:07 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I still will never get what all the rage is on bolas, ive played against him many times. My simple solution:
  
1. Faiths fetters bolas
  
2. clear out your opponents defenses with your big creatures, you've had time to play them becasue of bolas's high cost
  
3. kill bolas with your creatures, you shouldnt have taken too much damage from him at this point
  
4. if you have a planeswalker, play it (if you dont have one skip this step)
  
5. move on to your opponent for the win
  
My recomendation is use the divine deck (in duel decks "divine vs. demonic") and add in ajani goldmane and/or elspeth (both planeswalkers) if you have them. You might want to take out one charging paladin and then, if your adding a second card, angelic protector. akroma hurts bad, good for killing bolas. do this and bolas wont provide you with any trouble. the only thing is your way, is getting faith's fetters or the divine deck :P.
posts.html:

posts.post_content: No doubt that Nicol Bolas is a very powerful card but it is little bit expensive to summon. Nicol Bolas is suitable for the decks which has land and artifact destroyer cards in it. You must slow downs your opponent in order to summon Nicol Bolas. Your target lands must be Islands (for counter spells) and Mountains (for direct damages to Nicol Bolas). And better you have some mid and low power creatures to defend yourself.
posts.html:

You must slow downs your opponent in order to summon Nicol Bolas. Your target lands must be Islands (for counter spells) and Mountains (for direct damages to Nicol Bolas). And better you have some mid and low power creatures to defend yourself.

posts.post_content: I have rarely come across a deck that used him in the area I play FNM at, but from what I have seen he isn't that great. Sure he can come out and destroy something or take a creature from someone. All you need to do is use either Celestial Purge, Scourgl\*\*\* or a few other cards and he is gone. When I went up against someone that used him he didnt make it to my turn and I always got back what he took or destroyed.

posts.post_content: A supply of endless "destroy enchantment" effects that can also take annoying equipment off the board or destroy lands would be good enough, but he can even take over enemy creatures. Those alone would be worth eight mana as far as I'm concerned, but then he can unleash a powered-up version of Cruel Ultimatum, which not only deals fairly noticable damage and forces your opponent to discard their entire hand, but will likely force them to either mana-screw themselves or clear the table of blockers, allowing you to end the game in that combat phase. God I love this card.
posts.html:

God I love this card.

Posted By: God_of_Destruction (6/27/2009 10:51:21 PM)

posts.post_content:
This is an excellent, underrated card for Spikes. It's also obviously good for Timmies and Vorthoses. Sorry Johnny.  
  
Any control deck that runs Grixis colors should run at least one copy of this guy. He's an excellent finisher, especially against the midrange decks that are dominating the meta. If you drop this guy, you will win unless your opponent manages to find an answer very quickly.  
  
The mana is actually a little bit better than Cruel Ultimatum in a lot of decks, so I don't know why people complain about that so much. You're certainly getting enough bang for your buck.
posts.html:
This is an excellent, underrated card for Spikes. It's also obviously good for Timmies and Vorthoses. Sorry Johnny.

Any control deck that runs Grixis colors should run at least one copy of this guy. He's an excellent finisher, especially against the midrange decks that are dominating the meta. If you drop this guy, you will win unless your opponent manages to find an answer very quickly.

The mana is actually a little bit better than Cruel Ultimatum in a lot of decks, so I don't know why people complain about that so much. You're certainly getting enough bang for your buck.
